Dear Dr Carter,
div1.p:
First let me thank you
for the delightful day I spent
with in Washington. I wish
you were strong enough so
that all younger men
might come and listen
to you. It would be worth
to them more than any
stereotyped stuff they may
get even out of the best text book.

I read section three of
your book with a great
deal of interest, also a great
deal of admiration. To dig
into those ancient docu-
ments in strange tongues
and unravel the mystery
hidden in a few vague
statements and marshal
these together to present
a convincing argument

Your argument is so con-
vincing; and the fact that
a serious of definitely recog-
nized epidemics appeared
with explosive suddenness
from 1648 on, seems to
me sufficient proof that
it de yellow fever did not
originate in the West Indies.
I am very glad that you
were able to clear up this
point. And I hope that
you will retain your
vigor long enough to be
be able to complete this
important work.

I had a very interesting
time with Darling and
Griffiths and learned a
great deal. Unfortunately
the heavy rains prevented
me from seeing impounded
